>  I wasn't saying there

is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> a =
machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> effort =
- it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> adding a r=
equirement to understand form processing rules) without
> delivering much b=
y way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> much to the table, and=
 many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> around it anyway. This may=
 well improve in the future but right now it
> doesn't seem like a good opt=
ion from the practical, cost-benefit point
> of view (not the architectural=
ly pure one).

A benefit of forms is that they can provide data to include =
in the corresponding submission that needs not or must not (due to volatili=
ty) be remembered by the client.

An example would be the current price of =
an item. Instead of constructing an order and including a remembered price,=
 the current price can be right in the form for the client to review and th=
en put into the submission request.

I was sort of against forms, but Ian S=
. Robinson totally changed my mind on this about a year ago when pointing t=
he above out to me.

Jan
